utterances: The war is very unpopular with a lot of independents and a lot of Democrats all over the Philly suburbs.
I mean this is the story everywhere.
It's, you know, the Republican candidates are running on the local issues.
You see, you know, signs that say our Congressmen or an independent voice.
They're trying to advertise how far apart they are from the president, whenever they voted against him and how far they are from the House leadership.
I mean Jim Gerlach, the incumbent here in the 6th District, his signs are kind of instructive, I think.
They're colored blue, they're not red.
You know, this is a Republican running with a blue sign.
They don't say Republican on them and you don't see any elephant.
You know, you see no identification with the party whatsoever.
It just says Jim Gerlach, our Congressman.
So you see the Republicans definitely running away from an unpopular war and a pretty unpopular president.
And statewide, a couple of critical races - for the governor's office, of course, and in the United States Senate, Rick Santorum, the Republican incumbent, a very tough race for him.
Yeah, he's on the ropes.
A lot of polls have showed the challenger, Bob Casey, running ahead, like all year.
Even at this late date, I think that the latest poll I saw still showed Casey up by about eight points.
So, yeah, this has been a very tough year for Rick Santorum.
And Governor Ed Rendell running against somebody's who's hailed as a sports hero in the state of Pennsylvania.
There you go.
â€¦instead of me trying to direct it so much?
But Lynn Swann was a newcomer to politics and it was just a tough year for him to run against a very popular governor.
You know, the economy is not going too badly in Pennsylvania and Governor Rendell has been able to run on a, you know, on having fulfilled a lot of his campaign promises.
And, you know, people like him in Pennsylvania.
He's very popular statewide and polls show him running away with the reelection race.
Ken Rudin, any chance for Rick Santorum?
No.
Joe is exactly right.
Whether it's been one point or by 20 points, Santorum has trailed all year.

No Republican senator has been defeated in Pennsylvania in 50 years, but Santorum has never caught on, and it looks like more and more Republicans are going for Bob Casey, who's a far less effective campaigner.
Santorum is a better campaigner, has more money, but it's not the right year, and the issues are not on his side.
Joel Rose, thanks very much for your time.
We appreciate it.
Oh, it was my pleasure.
Thanks for having me.
Joel Rose reports for our member station in Philadelphia, WHYY, and he joined us by phone today from the suburbs of Philadelphia.
And let's see if we can get one more caller on the line, and this is Charlie(ph), Charlie calling from Wichita in Kansas.
Hi.
I was greatly concerned - in our primary in Kansas, we had basically a state-wide turnout of 18 percent.
My question is, for you guys who are experts back there looking at the whole country, has this mid-term election, is it going to bring out a higher percentage of voter turnout?
Ken?
Well, it'll certainly bring out a lot of Democrats, and my guess is it'll bring out fewer Republicans.
I don't know if more - I mean, numerically, there's always more people who vote, but this year, all around the country, the primary turnout was really abysmal.
I think it was like 8 percent in Virginia.
Oh my gosh.
So it's really - but I don't get a sense that that will be reflected tomorrow.
I really think that, you know - from at least anecdotally or the people I speak to - Democrats are really pumped up about this.
Now there may be more interest among Republicans in the last couple of days.
They seem to be maybe, you know, coming back from the fold, but I think the Democrats are really, really anxiously awaiting this.
This election can't happen soon enough for them.
Okay.
Thank you very much for the program.
Thanks very much for your call, Charlie.
Bye.
And finally, Ken, last week you gave us some tentative predictions.
We're going to put you on the spot again.
How many seats do the Democrats pick up, and I think that's what we're talking about, definitely Democratic gains in the House of Representatives.
In the House, then need 15 to make Nancy Pelosi speaker.
I have a net gain of 24 for the Democrats, including one seat in Vermont, which was held by an independent, a pick-up of 24.
They pick up four seats in the Senate, but not enough to win control.
They need six to win control.
I see them only winning four, and they pick up maybe eight seats, eight governorships, as well - a good year for Democratic governors.
A very tired, but nevertheless manic, Ken Rudin will be with us on Wednesday, and we can check all those numbers with him as we report on the results of tomorrow's election.
Ken Rudin, thanks very much for being with us.
Thanks, Neal.
NPR's political editor, Ken Rudin, and the Political Junkie column at npr.org.
When we come back, The Opinion Page.
Do you remember the electric car before all those hybrids and what-not at an auto show way back in 1990?
GM unveiled a concept car called the Impact and in 1996 the Impact was made into the EV-1, which made it to the market, and then for a few years people could lease an electric car.
None were sold, only leased, and it was the fastest - among the fastest, most efficient production cars ever built.
It ran on electricity.
It produced no emissions, catapulted American technology to the forefront of the automotive industry, and the lucky few who drove it never wanted to give it up.
So why did General Motors crush its fleet of EV-1 electric vehicles into the Arizona desert?
That's the question in the synopsis of, Who Killed the Electric Car?
that is coming out in theaters near you.
And Chris Paine is a former EV-1 driver and he is a director of the film.
It's opening in L.A.
and New York and he joins us from our NPR West studio.
Welcome to the program, Chris.
Hey, thank you.
You know, I asked a spokesperson - or I asked GM to send somebody to come and talk about it, and they refused to talk about it.
Why do you - why do you suspect that is?
Well, they spoke with us.
So I think, you know, there's a lot of attention on this issue right now.
And they're probably being very careful about what they want to say.
Hm-hmm.
You know, I wish they would talk because they have - you know, GM really created its best car they ever drove, in my estimation, and those of us who got to drive these cars.
And I think this kind of technology could really put GM back on the map.
But they'd have to reorient their corporate culture off of the internal combustion engine, which I think is going to be pretty tough.
Hm-hmm.
We're talking with Chris Paine, director of the new documentary, Who Killed the Electric Car?
It's out this week from Sony Pictures, Sony Classics.
You know, the most sad part of the movie - and I'm sure it was sad for the car owners who were not allowed to own it, right?
You see in the film the cars are just being crushed, beautiful brand new looking cars coming off these flatbed trailers just being put in the shredder.
I know.
It was really shocking.
And when it all happened, we just stood there and said, what are you guys doing?
You've really made an amazing car.
And most Americans never even knew there were production electric cars.
So the sight of seeing them destroyed before most people ever got to experience them was really quite a shocking moment for us.
Hm-hmm.
Go ahead.
I've got about a minute, but go ahead, Chris.
And I think the reason I wanted to break that cycle is because I didn't want my four children to grow up and look at my mom or my dad - or even me or their father - that we didn't something good.
I made many mistakes in my life.
I don't like that I even had to be subjected to know about people that were murdered.
That's a horrible, horrible life.
And I to got ask.
Given that, today, now that you're in relative safety in Pennsylvania - you've got a kid in construction.
Mm hmm.
You've got a couple of kids who are teenagers now.
Mm hmm.
What do you worry about?
Actually, it's funny because my 17-year-old - I worry about him very much with - I mean, even living in a beautiful area in the suburbs, there's all kinds of crimes there.
There's lot of drugs.
There's probably more drugs there than there are in the city because there's money, and that's scary to me.
The two older ones are doing good.
They both work together in the construction business.
But the 17-year-old, you know, jury is out on him.
I try and talk to him everyday.
He's a little rough around the edges, but teenagers are always striving for freedom and independence.
And I think it's scary -scary for me.
You told us what advice your mother gave you, to go out and marry a mobster.

What advice are you giving her?
